Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Oxygen Reduction Catalysis at Tunable Metal Sulfide Nanofilms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Renewable energy sources such as solar and wind will play an increasing role in meeting the growing energy demands of the future. However, these sources are intermittent, having reliable energy when the sun doesn't shine or wind doesn't blow requires storage in an energy dense form such as a chemical fuel. The fuel energy can then be released to produce electricity on demand in a fuel cell. Currently, fuel cells are expensive and unsustainable due to the high cost and scarcity of the platinum-based catalysts needed to convert fuel to electricity. This project aims to develop low-cost, non-toxic, earth-abundant catalysts to replace platinum in future fuel cells. The work will allow graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows to learn the modern techniques in chemistry for renewable energy science and to collaborate to discover new catalysts. The research work will also be integrated with a broad-based outreach effort, The Catalyst Genome Project, which will allow amateur researchers of all ages to discover, evaluate, and collaborate in the search for new catalysts for renewable energy storage.

With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Yogesh Surendranath of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to systematically investigate the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) mediated by late transition metal sulfide (MSx where M = Ni, Co, Fe) nanofilm electrocatalysts. Late transition metal sulfides (LTMSs) represent an attractive class of low-cost, earth-abundant ORR catalysts for low-temperature fuel cell cathodes but their development and optimization have been hampered by a lack of mechanistic understanding and an absence of fundamental design principles. The project will utilize a recently developed layer-by-layer chemical electrodeposition method for preparing nanometer-thick crystalline LTMS films to probe the active site structure and mechanism of ORR on these materials. From these studies, the work aims to extract broad periodic trends and overarching design principles that will be used to synthesize high-performance nanoparticulate LTMS ORR catalysts primed for integration into advanced fuel cell cathodes

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a combustion engine, fuel and oxygen are burned to produce energy. At the chemical level, fuel is oxidized and oxygen is reduced meaning that electrons have transferred from the fuel to oxygen in the exhausted carbon dioxide and water. Fuel cells perform these oxidations and reductions at two electrodes, fuel oxidation transfers electrons to an anode wired to a cathode which transfers it to oxygen. The electrical current generated between the two electrodes is the direct conversion of the chemical energy to electrical energy. Whereas the combustion engine is ubiquitous, wide-spread deployment of fuel cells requires the identification of electrode materials that can catalyze the oxidation of fuels such as hydrogen gas, methanol, or formate as well as the reduction of oxygen gas that are cheap and abundant. The work supported by this grant has furthered the understanding of how metal chalcogenides (specifically oxides, sulfides, and selenides) perform as alternative electrode materials to more expensive and less abundant materials such as platinum.

Through computational and experimental assessment, we identified nickel sulfides (e.g. Ni3S2, NiS, NiS2) as promising oxygen reduction cathodes. Prior cathode materials require highly caustic aqueous electrolytes for stability or rapid reactions, these nickel sulfide materials operate with neutral electrolytes similar to microbial fuel cell technology. Notably, though, a proof-of-concept fuel cell constructed with a Ni3S2 cathode gave power densities 10-fold greater than the latter and double that of an identical device employing a platinum cathode instead. Moreover, even in presence of formate and methanol fuels these cathodes selectively reduced oxygen. Lack of selectivity is pernicious problem in fuel cells. As both fuel oxidation and oxygen reduction occurring at the same electrode does not contribute to the external electrical current and is lost energy. A membrane is typically used in fuel cells where the electrodes are not selective. These membranes introduce device architecture complexity, cost, and ionic resistance energy loss. Our demonstrated device was able to operate membrane-less given the selectivity of the nickel sulfide catalyst.

In studying these materials, we: (1) constructed a “Pourbaix diagram” which is used to determine stability of different phases of these materials; (2) discovered that post-operando a few- -nanometer-thick, amorphous surface phase forms with equal parts Ni and S; and (3) determined this to be the active surface. Further studies showed that this surface forms via a self-limiting leaching of Ni ions until a protective coating of NiS forms and that the atomic structure of the active site is a Ni atom coordinated with three neighboring S atoms. Using this coordination-number description of the active site, we were able generalize a model that predicts the activity across the family of nickel sulfide materials. Taken together these fundamental insights will help to guide future design of earth-abundant oxygen reduction catalysts.

We also developed anodes composed primarily of an earth-abundant metal chalcogenide that exhibited similarly excellent selectivity towards hydrogen oxidation. We fabricated tungsten oxide (WOx) membranes decorated with nanoparticulates of platinum. These membranes transport hydrogen from the gas phase to be oxidized at the electrolyte, via hydrogen spillover from Pt to WOx. These composite electrodes use much less precious metal while achieving 26-fold higher current densities relative to planar platinum electrodes. Moreover, the Pt/WOx composite tolerates oxygen and common poisons dissolved in the electrolyte. From a mechanistic model, we showed that the activity of these electrodes is gated by the amount of the triple-interface where the WOx, platinum, and gas meet which indicates Pt-to-WOx spillover as rate limiting in these systems.

Benchmarking exploratory materials, such as those we studied above, is necessary for making fair comparisons. For instance, the activity of an electrode depends on its surface area; doubling the surface area of an electrode will double the reaction rate or electrical power. As such, the activity of the electrode must be normalized to this area. As measuring the surface area of electrodes with atomic-scale structuring and roughness can be challenging, we established a new, practical, and simple measurement. Importantly, in electrochemical systems, the capacitance of ions layered at the electrode interface is a readily measurable and is proportional to the interfacial area. We showed that electrolyte ions that do not adsorb on the electrode, such as potassium hexafluorophosphate in acetonitrile, generally exhibit specific capacitances indifferent to the electrode material. Consequently, the surface area of the electrode can be calculated from this capacitance and we showed this measure agrees with prior state-of-the-art methods.

Throughout the duration of this project we regularly hosted a laboratory module at a majority-minority local high school that teaches the scientific principals underpinning the aforementioned research as well as shares our enthusiasm for discovery science with the students. For wider dissemination, electronic resources for this module are available online.
